name: American Ginseng (Panax quinquefolius)
summary: An herbal supplement traditionally used for fatigue, cognitive support, and immune modulation. Studied for benefits in energy, mental performance, and blood sugar regulation.
description: American Ginseng (Panax quinquefolius) is a perennial plant native to North America. It contains ginsenosides, active compounds thought to influence energy metabolism, stress response, and cognition. Unlike Asian ginseng (Panax ginseng), American ginseng is considered to have a more calming effect. It has been used in traditional medicine for enhancing vitality, improving memory, reducing fatigue, and modulating blood sugar. Clinical studies suggest modest benefits for mental performance, fatigue in cancer patients, and glycemic control in diabetes.

metadata.fda_status: Not FDA-approved; marketed as dietary supplement in U.S.

items: Adjunct for glycemic control in type 2 diabetes

sections.text: Contains ginsenosides, which modulate the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal (HPA) axis, neurotransmitter systems, and glucose metabolism. Acts as an adaptogen, enhancing resilience to physical and mental stressors.

adult.usual_range: 200–1,000 mg daily of standardized extract (4–7% ginsenosides)
adult.cognitive_support: 200–400 mg single dose or divided daily

sections.geriatric: Generally considered safe in lower range doses; monitor blood pressure and glucose

sections.text: Acute cognitive effects reported within hours; fatigue and glucose control benefits may require weeks of use.

other: Use with caution in patients with diabetes; risk of additive hypoglycemia with medications.
Can cause insomnia if taken late in the day.

sections.pregnancy: Not enough safety data; avoid use
sections.pediatrics: Not recommended due to lack of safety data
sections.geriatrics: May be beneficial in fatigue or cognitive decline; monitor for BP/glucose changes

sections.text: No formal tapering required; some traditional practices recommend cycling use.

items: American ginseng is chemically distinct from Asian ginseng, with different ginsenoside profiles and effects.
Some evidence supports use in cancer-related fatigue, especially in patients undergoing chemotherapy.
Often included in adaptogenic blends with rhodiola, ashwagandha, or schisandra.
